-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 1 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

[STDOUT from UI.py]: What is the title of your invention?:

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 1 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 1 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

[STDOUT from UI.py]: What is the title of your invention?:

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 1 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------

[STDOUT from UI.py]: What is the title of your invention?:

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 1 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The claim of the patent application is word‑for‑word identical to the claim presented as the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a) to (f) for determining condensation risk using an IR camera, mean indoor temperature and humidity, calculation of a condensation temperature, comparison, identification of risky points, and colouring the image. Because the claimed subject‑matter is fully disclosed in the prior art, there is no technical contribution that would not have been directly and unambiguously derivable from the prior art. Under the European Patent Convention, a claim that is not novel or that does not involve an inventive step (i.e., would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art) is not patentable. Consequently, the claimed method lacks an inventive step.",
  "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."
}

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (document D1) is described only as a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals. The claim, however, recites a specific computer‑implemented method for brokering freight transport offers and demands that includes: (a) receiving offers/demands together with location and time data; (b) receiving current GPS locations of the users; (c) checking whether there are previously received but unsatisfied offers/demands that could satisfy a new request; (d) if such offers/demands exist, selecting the one whose users are geographically closest; and (e) otherwise storing the new request. None of these additional functional steps (verification of unsatisfied requests, selection based on closest current locations, and conditional storage) are disclosed in D1. Because the only disclosed feature in D1 is the receipt of GPS location data, the claim adds further technical features that are not directly or implicitly taught by D1. No other prior art is provided that would render these additional steps obvious to a person skilled in the art. Consequently, the claimed method contains distinguishing features that are not derivable in an obvious manner from D1, satisfying the requirement of an inventive step under the EPO problem‑solution approach.",
  "answer": "The claim involves an inventive step over the closest prior art D1."
}

The claim, however, recites a specific computer\u2011implemented method for brokering freight transport offers and demands that includes: (a) receiving offers/demands together with location and time data; (b) receiving current GPS locations of the users; (c) checking whether there are previously received but unsatisfied offers/demands that could satisfy a new request; (d) if such offers/demands exist, selecting the one whose users are geographically closest; and (e) otherwise storing the new request. CURRENT QUESTION:

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method that (i) applies material by a spray jet, (ii) monitors particle properties in real time, (iii) compares actual values with target values, and (iv) automatically adjusts process parameters using a neural‑network‑based controller. Claim 1 contains all of these features. The only distinguishing feature is that the controller is a neuro‑fuzzy controller that combines a neural network with fuzzy‑logic rules. The case data does not provide any teaching, suggestion, or motivation in D1 (or elsewhere) to replace the pure neural‑network controller with a neuro‑fuzzy controller. Consequently, a person skilled in the art would not be prompted by the prior art to make this specific technical modification. Because the modification is not directly disclosed and there is no indication that it would have been obvious to combine fuzzy‑logic rules with the neural network for this purpose, the claim involves an inventive step over D1.\n\nTherefore, the claim meets the requirement of inventive step under the European Patent Convention.",
  "answer": "Inventive step is present – the claim is not obvious over D1."
}

controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

CURRENT QUESTION:

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The problem‑solution approach therefore is: (i) identify D1 as the closest prior art; (ii) define the technical problem as providing a broadcast transmission that adapts to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection; (iii) assess whether the skilled person would arrive at the claimed features in an obvious manner. The only teaching in D1 is to use the maximum data rate; D1 does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower ‘available’ rate nor the use of that rate for transmission. No other document or teaching is supplied that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum‑rate transmission with a lower, dynamically‑available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not rendered obvious by D1 alone, and, in the absence of any further teaching, the claimed subject‑matter involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.",
  "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."
}
------------------------------------------------------------

[STDIN to UI.py]: The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step.

USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The problem\u2011solution approach therefore is: (i) identify D1 as the closest prior art; (ii) define the technical problem as providing a broadcast transmission that adapts to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection; (iii) assess whether the skilled person would arrive at the claimed features in an obvious manner. The only teaching in D1 is to use the maximum data rate; D1 does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for transmission. No other document or teaching is supplied that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not rendered obvious by D1 alone, and, in the absence of any further teaching, the claimed subject\u2011matter involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}

CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------


[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method in which a mobile user selects a product, the server determines the nearest vendor and transmits this information. The distinguishing features of claim 1 are: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" for purchasing the selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nApplying the EPO problem‑solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as: \"How to enable a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip to the relevant vendors.\" \n\nBoth the idea of handling multiple items and the concept of determining an optimal route are well‑known in the art (e.g., routing, travelling‑salesman and logistics literature). The use of a cache to store pre‑computed routes is a routine computer‑science optimisation that a skilled person would readily consider to improve performance. Consequently, the combination of these features would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art seeking to extend D1’s single‑product nearest‑vendor function to a multi‑product scenario. No technical effect beyond the known advantages of reduced computation time is demonstrated. Therefore, the subject‑matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step under Article 56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.",
  "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."
}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 2 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

Claim 1 contains all of these features. The only distinguishing feature is that the controller is a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller that combines a neural network with fuzzy\u2011logic rules. The case data does not provide any teaching, suggestion, or motivation in D1 (or elsewhere) to replace the pure neural\u2011network controller with a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller. --- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (document D1) is described only as a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals. The claim, however, recites a specific computer\u2011implemented method for brokering freight transport offers and demands that includes: (a) receiving offers/demands together with location and time data; (b) receiving current GPS locations of the users; (c) checking whether there are previously received but unsatisfied offers/demands that could satisfy a new request; (d) if such offers/demands exist, selecting the one whose users are geographically closest; and (e) otherwise storing the new request. None of these additional functional steps (verification of unsatisfied requests, selection based on closest current locations, and conditional storage) are disclosed in D1. Because the only disclosed feature in D1 is the receipt of GPS location data, the claim adds further technical features that are not directly or implicitly taught by D1. -------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 4 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

Because the claimed subject\u2011matter is fully disclosed in the prior art, there is no technical contribution that would not have been directly and unambiguously derivable from the prior art. Under the European Patent Convention, a claim that is not novel or that does not involve an inventive step (i.e., would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art) is not patentable. Consequently, the claimed method lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The technical effect of these features is that the system can adapt the transmission rate to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection and potentially improving quality of service. \n\nApplying the EPO problem‑solution approach:\n1. **Closest prior art** – D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Objective technical problem** – Provide a broadcast transmission method that adapts to the real‑time bandwidth that is actually available on the subscriber’s DSL line, rather than always using the nominal maximum rate.\n3. **Inventive step assessment** – D1 teaches only the use of the maximum data rate stored for each subscriber. It does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower ‘available’ rate nor the use of that rate for determining the transmission speed. No further teaching is supplied in the case data that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum‑rate transmission with a lower, dynamically‑available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not obvious to the person skilled in the art based on D1 alone. \nTherefore, the subject‑matter of claim 1 involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.",
  "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."

Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The problem\u2011solution approach therefore is: (i) identify D1 as the closest prior art; (ii) define the technical problem as providing a broadcast transmission that adapts to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection; (iii) assess whether the skilled person would arrive at the claimed features in an obvious manner. The only teaching in D1 is to use the maximum data rate; D1 does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for transmission. No other document or teaching is supplied that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not rendered obvious by D1 alone, and, in the absence of any further teaching, the claimed subject\u2011matter involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 5 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

Because the claimed subject\u2011matter is fully disclosed in the prior art, there is no technical contribution that would not have been directly and unambiguously derivable from the prior art. Under the European Patent Convention, a claim that is not novel or that does not involve an inventive step (i.e., would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art) is not patentable. Consequently, the claimed method lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}

CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------


[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art D1 discloses a method where a mobile user selects a single product, the server determines the nearest vendor and sends this information to the device. The claimed invention differs from D1 in three respects: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" covering all selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nUnder the EPO problem‑solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as providing a method that enables a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip, while reducing the computational effort required to determine such a trip. \n\nBoth handling multiple items and determining an optimal route (a travelling‑salesman‑type problem) are well‑known in the art. Routing and logistics literature, as well as numerous computer‑science publications, teach that when several destinations must be visited, an optimal tour can be calculated. The use of a cache (or memoisation) to store previously computed routes to avoid recalculating them is a routine optimisation known to skilled programmers for improving performance of routing algorithms. \n\nConsequently, a person skilled in the art, starting from D1 and seeking to extend the single‑product nearest‑vendor function to a multi‑product scenario, would readily combine the known teaching of multi‑item selection with the known techniques for route optimisation and caching. The combination does not produce any unexpected technical effect beyond the obvious advantages of reduced computation time and a more convenient user experience, which are themselves predictable. Therefore, the subject‑matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step under Article 56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.",
  "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."
}
------------------------------------------------------------

[STDIN to UI.py]: The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious).
[STDOUT from UI.py]: What is the technical field of the invention?:

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 3 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method in which a mobile user selects a product, the server determines the nearest vendor and transmits this information. The distinguishing features of claim\u202f1 are: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" for purchasing the selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nApplying the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as: \"How to enable a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip to the relevant vendors.\" \n\nBoth the idea of handling multiple items and the concept of determining an optimal route are well\u2011known in the art (e.g., routing, travelling\u2011salesman and logistics literature). The use of a cache to store pre\u2011computed routes is a routine computer\u2011science optimisation that a skilled person would readily consider to improve performance. Consequently, the combination of these features would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art seeking to extend D1\u2019s single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario. No technical effect beyond the known advantages of reduced computation time is demonstrated. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim\u202f1 lacks an inventive step under Article\u202f56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art D1 discloses a method where a mobile user selects a single product, the server determines the nearest vendor and sends this information to the device. The claimed invention differs from D1 in three respects: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" covering all selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nUnder the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as providing a method that enables a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip, while reducing the computational effort required to determine such a trip. \n\nBoth handling multiple items and determining an optimal route (a travelling\u2011salesman\u2011type problem) are well\u2011known in the art. Routing and logistics literature, as well as numerous computer\u2011science publications, teach that when several destinations must be visited, an optimal tour can be calculated. The use of a cache (or memoisation) to store previously computed routes to avoid recalculating them is a routine optimisation known to skilled programmers for improving performance of routing algorithms. \n\nConsequently, a person skilled in the art, starting from D1 and seeking to extend the single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario, would readily combine the known teaching of multi\u2011item selection with the known techniques for route optimisation and caching. The combination does not produce any unexpected technical effect beyond the obvious advantages of reduced computation time and a more convenient user experience, which are themselves predictable. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step under Article 56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The problem\u2011solution approach therefore is: (i) identify D1 as the closest prior art; (ii) define the technical problem as providing a broadcast transmission that adapts to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection; (iii) assess whether the skilled person would arrive at the claimed features in an obvious manner. The only teaching in D1 is to use the maximum data rate; D1 does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for transmission. No other document or teaching is supplied that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not rendered obvious by D1 alone, and, in the absence of any further teaching, the claimed subject\u2011matter involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The technical effect of these features is that the system can adapt the transmission rate to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection and potentially improving quality of service. \n\nApplying the EPO problem\u2011solution approach:\n1. **Closest prior art** \u2013 D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Objective technical problem** \u2013 Provide a broadcast transmission method that adapts to the real\u2011time bandwidth that is actually available on the subscriber\u2019s DSL line, rather than always using the nominal maximum rate.\n3. **Inventive step assessment** \u2013 D1 teaches only the use of the maximum data rate stored for each subscriber. It does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for determining the transmission speed. No further teaching is supplied in the case data that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not obvious to the person skilled in the art based on D1 alone. \nTherefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim 1 involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}

  "reasoning": "The patent claim is word‑for‑word identical to the claim presented as the closest prior art. [STDIN to UI.py]: The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art.

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 6 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The claim of the patent application is word\u2011for\u2011word identical to the claim presented as the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a) to (f) for determining condensation risk using an IR camera, mean indoor temperature and humidity, calculation of a condensation temperature, comparison, identification of risky points, and colouring the image. Because the claimed subject\u2011matter is fully disclosed in the prior art, there is no technical contribution that would not have been directly and unambiguously derivable from the prior art. Under the European Patent Convention, a claim that is not novel or that does not involve an inventive step (i.e., would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art) is not patentable. Consequently, the claimed method lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The patent claim is identical, word\u2011for\u2011word, to the closest prior art claim. === CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 5 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method in which a mobile user selects a product, the server determines the nearest vendor and transmits this information. The distinguishing features of claim\u202f1 are: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" for purchasing the selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nApplying the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as: \"How to enable a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip to the relevant vendors.\" \n\nBoth the idea of handling multiple items and the concept of determining an optimal route are well\u2011known in the art (e.g., routing, travelling\u2011salesman and logistics literature). The use of a cache to store pre\u2011computed routes is a routine computer\u2011science optimisation that a skilled person would readily consider to improve performance. Consequently, the combination of these features would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art seeking to extend D1\u2019s single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario. No technical effect beyond the known advantages of reduced computation time is demonstrated. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim\u202f1 lacks an inventive step under Article\u202f56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art D1 discloses a method where a mobile user selects a single product, the server determines the nearest vendor and sends this information to the device. The claimed invention differs from D1 in three respects: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" covering all selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nUnder the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as providing a method that enables a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip, while reducing the computational effort required to determine such a trip. \n\nBoth handling multiple items and determining an optimal route (a travelling\u2011salesman\u2011type problem) are well\u2011known in the art. Routing and logistics literature, as well as numerous computer\u2011science publications, teach that when several destinations must be visited, an optimal tour can be calculated. The use of a cache (or memoisation) to store previously computed routes to avoid recalculating them is a routine optimisation known to skilled programmers for improving performance of routing algorithms. \n\nConsequently, a person skilled in the art, starting from D1 and seeking to extend the single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario, would readily combine the known teaching of multi\u2011item selection with the known techniques for route optimisation and caching. The combination does not produce any unexpected technical effect beyond the obvious advantages of reduced computation time and a more convenient user experience, which are themselves predictable. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step under Article 56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 5 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The problem\u2011solution approach therefore is: (i) identify D1 as the closest prior art; (ii) define the technical problem as providing a broadcast transmission that adapts to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection; (iii) assess whether the skilled person would arrive at the claimed features in an obvious manner. The only teaching in D1 is to use the maximum data rate; D1 does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for transmission. No other document or teaching is supplied that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not rendered obvious by D1 alone, and, in the absence of any further teaching, the claimed subject\u2011matter involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection and then transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it determines the transmission rate based on this available data rate rather than the maximum rate. The technical effect of these features is that the system can adapt the transmission rate to the actual bandwidth that can be used at a given moment, avoiding overload of the connection and potentially improving quality of service. \n\nApplying the EPO problem\u2011solution approach:\n1. **Closest prior art** \u2013 D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Objective technical problem** \u2013 Provide a broadcast transmission method that adapts to the real\u2011time bandwidth that is actually available on the subscriber\u2019s DSL line, rather than always using the nominal maximum rate.\n3. **Inventive step assessment** \u2013 D1 teaches only the use of the maximum data rate stored for each subscriber. It does not disclose, suggest or motivate the storage of a lower \u2018available\u2019 rate nor the use of that rate for determining the transmission speed. No further teaching is supplied in the case data that would lead the skilled person to replace the maximum\u2011rate transmission with a lower, dynamically\u2011available rate. Consequently, the modifications are not obvious to the person skilled in the art based on D1 alone. \nTherefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim 1 involves an inventive step under the European Patent Convention.", "answer": "The claim is inventive over D1; it involves an inventive step."}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 6 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method in which a mobile user selects a product, the server determines the nearest vendor and transmits this information. The distinguishing features of claim\u202f1 are: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" for purchasing the selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nApplying the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as: \"How to enable a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip to the relevant vendors.\" \n\nBoth the idea of handling multiple items and the concept of determining an optimal route are well\u2011known in the art (e.g., routing, travelling\u2011salesman and logistics literature). The use of a cache to store pre\u2011computed routes is a routine computer\u2011science optimisation that a skilled person would readily consider to improve performance. Consequently, the combination of these features would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art seeking to extend D1\u2019s single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario. No technical effect beyond the known advantages of reduced computation time is demonstrated. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim\u202f1 lacks an inventive step under Article\u202f56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art D1 discloses a method where a mobile user selects a single product, the server determines the nearest vendor and sends this information to the device. The claimed invention differs from D1 in three respects: (1) the user may select two or more products; (2) the server provides an \"optimal shopping tour\" covering all selected products; and (3) the optimal tour is obtained by consulting a cache that stores tours previously computed. \n\nUnder the EPO problem\u2011solution approach, the technical problem can be formulated as providing a method that enables a mobile user to purchase several selected products in a single, efficient trip, while reducing the computational effort required to determine such a trip. \n\nBoth handling multiple items and determining an optimal route (a travelling\u2011salesman\u2011type problem) are well\u2011known in the art. Routing and logistics literature, as well as numerous computer\u2011science publications, teach that when several destinations must be visited, an optimal tour can be calculated. The use of a cache (or memoisation) to store previously computed routes to avoid recalculating them is a routine optimisation known to skilled programmers for improving performance of routing algorithms. \n\nConsequently, a person skilled in the art, starting from D1 and seeking to extend the single\u2011product nearest\u2011vendor function to a multi\u2011product scenario, would readily combine the known teaching of multi\u2011item selection with the known techniques for route optimisation and caching. The combination does not produce any unexpected technical effect beyond the obvious advantages of reduced computation time and a more convenient user experience, which are themselves predictable. Therefore, the subject\u2011matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step under Article 56 EPC.\n\nConclusion: The claim is obvious and does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step (it is obvious)."}
