-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 35 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 36 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 25 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

  "reasoning": "The patent claim is word‑for‑word identical to the claim disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)–(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24 hours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point’s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject‑matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Consequently, under the European Patent Convention the claim lacks an inventive step.",

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 18 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 30 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 28 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 26 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------


[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The claimed method in the patent application is word‑for‑word identical to the method disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)–(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24 hours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point’s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject‑matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Under the European Patent Convention, the claim therefore lacks an inventive step.",
  "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."
}

[STDIN to UI.py]: The claim lacks an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art.
[STDOUT from UI.py]: Invalid input. Please enter a number.
Choose an answer (enter number):

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 19 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER:

Both describe the same sequence of steps (a) to (f): controlling an infrared camera to capture a temperature image of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that threshold as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject\u2011matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Under the European Patent Convention, the claim therefore does not involve an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}

Because the entire subject\u2011matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The patent claim is word\u2011for\u2011word identical to the claim disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)\u2013(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject\u2011matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Consequently, under the European Patent Convention the claim lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The claimed method in the patent application is word\u2011for\u2011word identical to the method disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)\u2013(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. === CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

CURRENT QUESTION:

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The claimed method in the patent application is word‑for‑word identical to the method disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)–(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24 hours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point’s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject‑matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Under the European Patent Convention, the claim therefore does not involve an inventive step.",

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 20 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

HISTORY:
USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The patent claim is word\u2011for\u2011word identical to the claim disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)\u2013(f): controlling an infrared camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject\u2011matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Consequently, under the European Patent Convention the claim lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------


[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method for controlling a thermal spray coating process in which a neural network analyses particle‑property data in real time and automatically adjusts process parameters. The claimed method differs from D1 only in that the controller is specified as a \"neuro‑fuzzy controller\" that combines a neural network with fuzzy‑logic rules. \n\nFor an inventive step under the EPO approach, the question is whether the modification would have been obvious to the skilled person starting from D1. \n\n1. **Technical problem** – The problem solved by the amendment can be framed as providing an alternative controller that may offer smoother or more interpretable decision‑making by incorporating fuzzy‑logic rules together with the neural‑network model. \n2. **Known alternatives** – Both neural networks and fuzzy‑logic controllers are well‑known in the field of process control. The combination of the two, often called a neuro‑fuzzy system, is a standard technique in control engineering and is taught in the literature as a way to combine the learning capability of neural networks with the rule‑based reasoning of fuzzy logic. \n3. **Obviousness** – Starting from D1, a skilled person seeking to improve the controller would be aware of the existence of neuro‑fuzzy approaches and could readily replace the pure neural‑network controller with a neuro‑fuzzy one to obtain the claimed features. No technical teaching or unexpected effect is presented in the case data that would render the combination non‑obvious. \n4. **Conclusion** – Because the only distinguishing feature is the use of a neuro‑fuzzy controller, which would have been an obvious modification for a skilled person, the claimed method lacks an inventive step over D1.\n\nTherefore, based on the information provided, the claim does not involve an inventive step under the EPO standards.",
  "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step. The only difference from D1 is the replacement of the pure neural‑network controller with a neuro‑fuzzy controller, a combination that would have been obvious to a skilled person familiar with neural‑network and fuzzy‑logic control techniques."
}
------------------------------------------------------------

[STDIN to UI.py]: The claim lacks an inventive step. The only difference from D1 is the replacement of the pure neural‑network controller with a neuro‑fuzzy controller, a combination that would have been obvious to a skilled person familiar with neural‑network and fuzzy‑logic control techniques.

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 38 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 21 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The claimed method in the patent application is word\u2011for\u2011word identical to the method disclosed in the closest prior art. Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)\u2013(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. Because the entire subject\u2011matter of the claim is directly and unambiguously disclosed in the prior art, a person skilled in the art would find the claimed method obvious. Under the European Patent Convention, the claim therefore lacks an inventive step.", "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step; it is obvious in view of the closest prior art."}
USER:

Both describe the same sequence of steps (a)\u2013(f): controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of a surface; receiving mean indoor air temperature and relative humidity values measured over the last 24\u202fhours; calculating a condensation temperature from those values; comparing each image point\u2019s temperature to the calculated condensation temperature; identifying points with a temperature lower than that condensation temperature as areas of increased condensation risk; and modifying the image by colouring those points to indicate the risk to a user. [USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 40 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a method for controlling a thermal spray coating process in which a neural network analyses particle\u2011property data in real time and automatically adjusts process parameters. The claimed method differs from D1 only in that the controller is specified as a \"neuro\u2011fuzzy controller\" that combines a neural network with fuzzy\u2011logic rules. \n\nFor an inventive step under the EPO approach, the question is whether the modification would have been obvious to the skilled person starting from D1. \n\n1. **Technical problem** \u2013 The problem solved by the amendment can be framed as providing an alternative controller that may offer smoother or more interpretable decision\u2011making by incorporating fuzzy\u2011logic rules together with the neural\u2011network model. \n2. **Known alternatives** \u2013 Both neural networks and fuzzy\u2011logic controllers are well\u2011known in the field of process control. The combination of the two, often called a neuro\u2011fuzzy system, is a standard technique in control engineering and is taught in the literature as a way to combine the learning capability of neural networks with the rule\u2011based reasoning of fuzzy logic. \n3. **Obviousness** \u2013 Starting from D1, a skilled person seeking to improve the controller would be aware of the existence of neuro\u2011fuzzy approaches and could readily replace the pure neural\u2011network controller with a neuro\u2011fuzzy one to obtain the claimed features. No technical teaching or unexpected effect is presented in the case data that would render the combination non\u2011obvious. \n4. **Conclusion** \u2013 Because the only distinguishing feature is the use of a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller, which would have been an obvious modification for a skilled person, the claimed method lacks an inventive step over D1.\n\nTherefore, based on the information provided, the claim does not involve an inventive step under the EPO standards.", "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step. The only difference from D1 is the replacement of the pure neural\u2011network controller with a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller, a combination that would have been obvious to a skilled person familiar with neural\u2011network and fuzzy\u2011logic control techniques."}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 22 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

1. Answer questions based ONLY on the text above.
2. Output valid JSON with keys 'reasoning' and 'answer'.

The claimed method differs from D1 only in that the controller is specified as a \"neuro\u2011fuzzy controller\" that combines a neural network with fuzzy\u2011logic rules. \n\nFor an inventive step under the EPO approach, the question is whether the modification would have been obvious to the skilled person starting from D1. \n\n1. **Technical problem** \u2013 The problem solved by the amendment can be framed as providing an alternative controller that may offer smoother or more interpretable decision\u2011making by incorporating fuzzy\u2011logic rules together with the neural\u2011network model. \n2. **Known alternatives** \u2013 Both neural networks and fuzzy\u2011logic controllers are well\u2011known in the field of process control. The combination of the two, often called a neuro\u2011fuzzy system, is a standard technique in control engineering and is taught in the literature as a way to combine the learning capability of neural networks with the rule\u2011based reasoning of fuzzy logic. \n3. **Obviousness** \u2013 Starting from D1, a skilled person seeking to improve the controller would be aware of the existence of neuro\u2011fuzzy approaches and could readily replace the pure neural\u2011network controller with a neuro\u2011fuzzy one to obtain the claimed features. No technical teaching or unexpected effect is presented in the case data that would render the combination non\u2011obvious. \n4. **Conclusion** \u2013 Because the only distinguishing feature is the use of a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller, which would have been an obvious modification for a skilled person, the claimed method lacks an inventive step over D1.\n\nTherefore, based on the information provided, the claim does not involve an inventive step under the EPO standards.", "answer": "The claim lacks an inventive step. The only difference from D1 is the replacement of the pure neural\u2011network controller with a neuro\u2011fuzzy controller, a combination that would have been obvious to a skilled person familiar with neural\u2011network and fuzzy\u2011logic control techniques."}

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): As a suitable starting point, document D1, which discloses a method of order management in which a server computer receives location information from GPS terminals, is selected as the closest prior art.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 23 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it uses this available data rate to determine the transmission rate instead of always using the maximum rate.\n\nTo assess inventive step under the European Patent Convention (EPC), we apply the problem‑solution approach:\n\n1. **Determine the closest prior art** – D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Establish the objective technical problem** – The problem can be formulated as “how to avoid over‑loading the data connection when the actual usable bandwidth is lower than the maximum capacity stored in the database”.\n3. **Identify the distinguishing features** – Storing an available (lower) data rate and using it to set the transmission rate.\n4. **Consider whether the skilled person would arrive at the solution in an obvious manner** – In the field of broadband video delivery, it is common knowledge that the maximum nominal DSL rate is not always achievable due to line conditions, congestion, or other temporary impairments. Adaptive bitrate streaming, congestion control, and dynamic rate adaptation are well‑known techniques in the art. A skilled person faced with the problem of preventing buffer underruns or excessive packet loss would naturally consider measuring or estimating the currently available bandwidth and adjusting the transmission rate accordingly. The modification of D1 to store a lower, currently available rate instead of the static maximum, and to use that value for rate selection, does not require any teaching beyond what is generally known in the networking community. No technical teaching or teaching away is present in D1 that would discourage such a modification.\n\nTherefore, the distinguishing features would have been obvious to the skilled person in view of D1 combined with the general knowledge of adaptive transmission in data networks.\n\n**Conclusion** – The subject‑matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step (Article 56 EPC) over D1.",
  "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; the differences over D1 would have been obvious to a skilled person."
}

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien

The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it uses this available data rate to determine the transmission rate instead of always using the maximum rate.\n\nTo assess inventive step under the European Patent Convention (EPC), we apply the problem\u2011solution approach:\n\n1. **Determine the closest prior art** \u2013 D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Establish the objective technical problem** \u2013 The problem can be formulated as \u201chow to avoid over\u2011loading the data connection when the actual usable bandwidth is lower than the maximum capacity stored in the database\u201d.\n3. **Identify the distinguishing features** \u2013 Storing an available (lower) data rate and using it to set the transmission rate.\n4. **Consider whether the skilled person would arrive at the solution in an obvious manner** \u2013 In the field of broadband video delivery, it is common knowledge that the maximum nominal DSL rate is not always achievable due to line conditions, congestion, or other temporary impairments. CURRENT QUESTION: 
------------------------------------------------------------


[LLM RESPONSE]:
{
  "reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) discloses a method in which a mobile‑device user selects a single product, the server determines the nearest vendor for that product and sends the vendor information to the device. The subject‑matter of claim 1 differs from D1 in three respects:\n\n1. **Selection of two or more products** – D1 is limited to a single product. The claim expands the scope to a set of products, which changes the nature of the problem from locating a single vendor to planning a multi‑stop purchase.\n\n2. **Provision of an \"optimal shopping tour\"** – D1 only returns the nearest vendor for the selected product; it does not propose any route or sequence for acquiring multiple items. Determining an optimal tour (e.g., minimizing travel distance or time) introduces a new technical requirement that is not taught or suggested by D1.\n\n3. **Use of a cache memory storing previously determined optimal tours** – D1 contains no teaching about re‑using earlier computed routes. Accessing a cache to retrieve a pre‑computed optimal tour is a distinct technical feature that improves efficiency but is not disclosed or implied by D1.\n\nTo assess inventive step under the EPO approach, the skilled person would start from D1 and the identified problem (providing a convenient way for a user to purchase several selected items with minimal travel). The question is whether the skilled person, using common general knowledge, would have been motivated to modify D1 in the direction of the three differences in an obvious manner.\n\n* The move from a single‑product selection to multiple products is not a trivial extension. D1’s teaching is centred on the nearest‑vendor concept; it provides no guidance on handling a set of products or on how to combine vendor locations.\n\n* The notion of an \"optimal shopping tour\" involves solving a routing optimisation problem (akin to the travelling‑salesman problem). While routing optimisation is known in the art, D1 does not address it, nor does it suggest that the server should compute such a route for a shopping purpose. Introducing this feature therefore requires a non‑obvious technical contribution.\n\n* The use of a cache to store previously computed tours adds another layer of technical effect (reduced computation time, faster response). D1 does not disclose any caching mechanism, and there is no indication that the skilled person would combine caching with the routing idea in the specific context of mobile shopping.\n\nBecause none of the three distinguishing features are disclosed, suggested, or rendered obvious by D1, and because their combination yields a technical solution that solves the problem of efficiently purchasing multiple items, the subject‑matter of claim 1 involves an inventive step.\n\nHence, based strictly on the provided case data, claim 1 would be considered to involve an inventive step over D1.",
  "answer": "Claim 1 involves an inventive step over the closest prior art (D1)."
}
------------------------------------------------------------

[STDIN to UI.py]: Claim 1 involves an inventive step over the closest prior art (D1).
[STDOUT from UI.py]: Invalid input. Please enter a number.
Choose an answer (enter number):

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 30 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method for brokering offers and demands in the field of transporting freight, comprising the following steps:

(a)
receiving transportation offers/demands from users, including location and time data;

(b)
receiving current location information of the users from GPS terminals with which the users are equipped;

(c)
after receiving a new offer/demand request, verifying if there are previous offers/demands not yet satisfied that can respond to the new request;

(d)
if so, selecting the one for which the current locations of both users are closest; and

(e)
otherwise storing the new request.
=== END CASE DATA ===

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 24 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A computer-implemented method of determining areas in which there is an increased risk of condensation for a surface in a building comprising the steps of:

(a)
controlling an infrared (IR) camera to capture an image of the temperature distribution of the surface;

(b)
receiving mean values for the air temperature and the relative air humidity measured inside the building over the last 24 hours;

(c)
calculating, based on said mean air temperature and mean relative air humidity, a condensation temperature at which there is a risk of condensation on the surface;

(d)
comparing the temperature at each point on the image to said calculated condensation temperature;

(e)
identifying the image points having a temperature lower than the calculated condensation temperature as areas at increased risk of condensation on the surface; and

(f)
modifying the image by colouring the image points identified in step (e) in a particular colour to indicate the areas at increased risk of condensation to a user.
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1 discloses a method for the control of a thermal spray coating process by applying material to a workpiece using a spray jet, detecting deviations in the properties of the particles in said spray jet and adjusting process parameters automatically on the basis of the outcome of a neural network analysis. This document represents the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The difference between the method of claim 1 and D1 concerns the use of a neuro-fuzzy controller combining a neural network and fuzzy logic rules as specified in the second part of step (d).

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A method for coating a workpiece using a thermal spray coating process, the method comprising:

(a)
applying, using a spray jet, a material to the workpiece by thermal spray coating;

(b)
monitoring the thermal spray coating process in real time by detecting properties of particles in the spray jet and supplying the properties as actual values;

(c)
comparing the actual values with target values;

and, in the event that the actual values deviate from the target values,

(d)
adjusting process parameters for the thermal spray coating process automatically by a controller on the basis of a neural network, said controller being a neuro-fuzzy controller which combines a neural-network and fuzzy logic rules and thereby maps statistical relationships between input variables and output variables of the neuro-fuzzy controller
=== END CASE DATA ===

=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a system for broadcasting video over an xDSL connection to the set-top boxes of subscribers, is selected as the closest prior art. The system comprises a database storing identifiers of subscribers' computers and, in association with them, an indication of the maximum data rate for the data connection to each subscriber's computer. The system further comprises means for transmitting the video to a subscriber's computer at the maximum data rate stored for said computer.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1) 
Storing an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client. 

(2) 
Using said available data rate to determine the rate at which the data is transmitted to the remote client (instead of transmitting the data at the maximum data rate stored for said remote client as in D1). 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

A system for the transmission of a broadcast media channel to a remote client over a data connection, said system including:

(a)
means for storing an identifier of the remote client and an indication of an available data rate of the data connection to the remote client, said available data rate being lower than the maximum data rate for the data connection to the remote client;

(b)
means for determining a rate at which data is to be transmitted based on the indication of the available data rate of the data connection; and

(c)
means for transmitting data at the determined rate to said remote clien
=== END CASE DATA ===

USER: 
ASSISTANT: {"reasoning": "The closest prior art (D1) already discloses a system that stores, for each subscriber, an identifier and the maximum data rate of the DSL connection, and transmits video at that maximum rate. The claimed invention differs from D1 in two respects: (1) it stores an indication of an *available* data rate that is lower than the maximum data rate, and (2) it uses this available data rate to determine the transmission rate instead of always using the maximum rate.\n\nTo assess inventive step under the European Patent Convention (EPC), we apply the problem\u2011solution approach:\n\n1. **Determine the closest prior art** \u2013 D1 is correctly identified.\n2. **Establish the objective technical problem** \u2013 The problem can be formulated as \u201chow to avoid over\u2011loading the data connection when the actual usable bandwidth is lower than the maximum capacity stored in the database\u201d.\n3. **Identify the distinguishing features** \u2013 Storing an available (lower) data rate and using it to set the transmission rate.\n4. **Consider whether the skilled person would arrive at the solution in an obvious manner** \u2013 In the field of broadband video delivery, it is common knowledge that the maximum nominal DSL rate is not always achievable due to line conditions, congestion, or other temporary impairments. Adaptive bitrate streaming, congestion control, and dynamic rate adaptation are well\u2011known techniques in the art. A skilled person faced with the problem of preventing buffer underruns or excessive packet loss would naturally consider measuring or estimating the currently available bandwidth and adjusting the transmission rate accordingly. The modification of D1 to store a lower, currently available rate instead of the static maximum, and to use that value for rate selection, does not require any teaching beyond what is generally known in the networking community. No technical teaching or teaching away is present in D1 that would discourage such a modification.\n\nTherefore, the distinguishing features would have been obvious to the skilled person in view of D1 combined with the general knowledge of adaptive transmission in data networks.\n\n**Conclusion** \u2013 The subject\u2011matter of claim 1 lacks an inventive step (Article 56 EPC) over D1.", "answer": "The claim does not involve an inventive step; the differences over D1 would have been obvious to a skilled person."}

-------------------- LLM PROMPT (Turn 31 | Mode: TOOL) --------------------
[USER]: You are assessing Inventive Step for the European Patent Office (EPO).
Use the provided CASE DATA strictly. Do not use outside knowledge but you can use your own interpretations of the given facts to reason.
=== CASE DATA ===
--- CLOSEST PRIOR ART ---
Step (ii): Document D1, which discloses a method for facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein the user selects a single product and the server determines from a database the vendor selling the selected product nearest to the user and transmits this information to the mobile device, is selected as the closest prior art.

Step (iii): The differences between the subject-matter of claim 1 and D1 are:

(1)
The user can select two or more products to purchase (instead of a single product only). 

(2)
An "optimal shopping tour" for purchasing the two or more products is provided to the user. 

(3)
The optimal shopping tour is determined by the server by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored. 

--- PATENT CLAIMS ---
Claim 1:

Method of facilitating shopping on a mobile device wherein:

(a)
the user selects two or more products to be purchased;

(b)
the mobile device transmits the selected products data and the device location to a server;

(c)
the server accesses a database of vendors to identify vendors offering at least one of the selected products;

(d)
the server determines, on the basis of the device location and the identified vendors, an optimal shopping tour for purchasing the selected products by accessing a cache memory in which optimal shopping tours determined for previous requests are stored; and

(e)
the server transmits the optimal shopping tour to the mobile device for displaying.
=== END CASE DATA ===
